@@\n+---\n+title: Protected actions are enabled for high-impact management tasks\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 09/23/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+# category: Privileged access\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Threat actors who gain privileged access to a tenant can manipulate identity, access, and security configurations. This type of attack can result in environment-wide compromise and loss of control over organizational assets. Take action to protect high-impact management tasks associated with Conditional Access policies, cross-tenant access settings, hard deletions, and network locations that are critical to maintaining security.\n+\n+Protected actions let administrators secure these tasks with extra security controls, such as stronger authentication methods (passwordless MFA or phishing-resistant MFA), the use of Privileged Access Workstation (PAW) devices, or shorter session timeouts.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Add, test, or remove protected actions in Microsoft Entra ID](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/protected-actions-add)" }, { "sha": "8b1db6269bd4dd3b3ed8c0f86670afab39360eb4", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21835.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 2, "deletions": 2, "changes": 4, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21835.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21835.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21835.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@ ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 08/26/2025\n+ms.date: 09/26/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation, sfi-ga-nochange\n # sfipillar: Protect engineering systems\n # category: Application management\n@@ -17,4 +17,4 @@ Microsoft recommends that organizations have two cloud-only emergency access acc\n \n **Remediation action**\n \n-Create accounts following the [emergency access account recommendations](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access).\n+- Create accounts following the [emergency access account recommendations](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access)." }, { "sha": "9174c8e7e5ff6534f5f744e5584908bcc7d87e23", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21837.md", "status": "added", "additions": 19, "deletions": 0, "changes": 19, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21837.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21837.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21837.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@\n+---\n+title: Limit the maximum number of devices per user to 10\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 09/26/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect engineering systems\n+# category: Devices\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Controlling device proliferation is important. Set a reasonable limit on the number of devices each user can register in your Microsoft Entra ID tenant. Limiting device registration maintains security while allowing business flexibility. Microsoft Entra ID lets users register up to 50 devices by default. Reducing this number to 10 minimizes the attack surface and simplifies device management.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- Learn how to [limit the maximum number of devices per user](/entra/identity/devices/manage-device-identities#configure-device-settings)." }, { "sha": "ce66d8a66355c7d79b2264f19b1ee66dae8e6119", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21839.md", "status": "added", "additions": 22, "deletions": 0, "changes": 22, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@\n+---\n+title: Passkey authentication method enabled\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/10/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+When passkey authentication isn't enabled in Microsoft Entra ID, organizations rely on password-based authentication methods that are vulnerable to phishing, credential theft, and replay attacks. Attackers can use stolen passwords to gain initial access, bypass traditional multifactor authentication through Adversary-in-the-Middle (AiTM) attacks, and establish persistent access through token theft.\n+\n+Passkeys provide phishing-resistant authentication using cryptographic proof that attackers can't phish, intercept, or replay. Enabling passkeys eliminates the foundational vulnerability that enables credential-based attack chains.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- Learn how to [enable the passkey authentication method](/entra/identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2#enable-passkey-fido2-authentication-method).\n+- Learn how to [plan a phishing-resistant passwordless authentication deployment](/entra/identity/authentication/how-to-plan-prerequisites-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication)." }, { "sha": "6a49b007bfd4346e909609bd0ea79c28d364f3ba", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21841.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Microsoft Authenticator app report suspicious activity setting is enabled\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/09/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Threat actors increasingly rely on prompt bombing and real-time phishing proxies to coerce or trick users into approving fraudulent multifactor authentication (MFA) challenges. Without the Microsoft Authenticator app's **Report suspicious activity** capability enabled, an attacker can iterate until a fatigued user accepts. This type of attack can lead to privilege escalation, persistence, lateral movement into sensitive workloads, data exfiltration, or destructive actions.\n+\n+When reporting is enabled for all users, any unexpected push or phone prompt can be actively flagged, immediately elevating the user to high user risk and generating a high-fidelity user risk detection (userReportedSuspiciousActivity) that risk-based Conditional Access policies or other response automation can use to block or require secure remediation. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Enable the report suspicious activity setting in the Microsoft Authenticator app](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-mfa-mfasettings#report-suspicious-activity)" }, { "sha": "ffee476a9c64b202a52962b147b14c00b7567cf8", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21845.md", "status": "added", "additions": 24, "deletions": 0, "changes": 24, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,24 @@\n+---\n+title: Temporary access pass is enabled\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/09/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Without Temporary Access Pass (TAP) enabled, organizations face significant challenges in securely bootstrapping user credentials, creating a vulnerability where users rely on weaker authentication mechanisms during their initial setup. When users cannot register phishing-resistant credentials like FIDO2 security keys or Windows Hello for Business due to lack of existing strong authentication methods, they remain exposed to credential-based attacks including phishing, password spray, or similar attacks. Threat actors can exploit this registration gap by targeting users during their most vulnerable state, when they have limited authentication options available and must rely on traditional username + password combinations. This exposure enables threat actors to compromise user accounts during the critical bootstrapping phase, allowing them to intercept or manipulate the registration process for stronger authentication methods, ultimately gaining persistent access to organizational resources and potentially escalating privileges before security controls are fully established. \n+\n+Enable TAP and use it with security info registration to secure this potential gap in your defenses.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Learn how to enable Temporary Access Pass in the Authentication methods policy](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-authentication-temporary-access-pass#enable-the-temporary-access-pass-policy)\n+- [Learn how to update authentication strength policies to include Temporary Access Pass](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options)\n+- [Learn how to create a Conditional Access policy for security info registration with authentication strength enforcement](/entra/identity/conditional-access/policy-all-users-security-info-registration)\n+ \n\\ No newline at end of file" }, { "sha": "c190dc68457835102ec62c4472322b44eea50b6f", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21848.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Add organizational terms to the banned password list\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/09/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Organizations that don't populate and enforce the custom banned password list expose themselves to a systematic attack chain where threat actors exploit predictable organizational password patterns. These threat actors typically start with reconnaissance phases, where they gather open-source intelligence (OSINT) from websites, social media, and public records to identify likely password components. With this knowledge, they launch password spray attacks that test organization-specific password variations across multiple user accounts, staying under lockout thresholds to avoid detection. Without the protection the custom banned password list offers, employees often add familiar organizational terms to their passwords, like locations, product names, and industry terms, creating consistent attack vectors. \n+\n+The custom banned password list helps organizations plug this critical gap to prevent easily guessed passwords that could lead to initial access and subsequent lateral movement within the environment.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Learn how to enable custom banned password protection and add organizational terms](/entra/identity/authentication/tutorial-configure-custom-password-protection)" }, { "sha": "f217e5f134c530a87c289ddb23388281575f4b63", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21850.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Smart lockout threshold set to 10 or less\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+When the smart lockout threshold is set to more than 10, threat actors can exploit the configuration to conduct reconnaissance, identify valid user accounts without triggering lockout protections, and establish initial access without detection. Once attackers gain initial access, they can move laterally through the environment by using the compromised account to access resources and escalate privileges.\n+\n+Smart lockout helps lock out bad actors who try to guess your users' passwords or use brute force methods to get in. Smart lockout recognizes sign-ins that come from valid users and treats them differently than ones of attackers and other unknown sources. A threshold of more than 10 provides insufficient protection against automated password spray attacks, making it easier for threat actors to compromise accounts while evading detection mechanisms. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Set Microsoft Entra smart lockout threshold to 10 or less](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-password-smart-lockout)." }, { "sha": "bce63f3f72f7dac91a56a74f9b5027dd3952a332", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21874.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 9, "deletions": 10, "changes": 19, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21874.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21874.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21874.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -1,22 +1,21 @@\n ---\n-title: Allow/Deny lists of domains to restrict external collaboration are configured\n-ms.author: sarahlipsey\n-author: shlipsey3\n+title: Guest access is limited to approved tenants\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 07/07/2025\n+ms.date: 10/10/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n # sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n # category: External collaboration\n # risklevel: Medium\n # userimpact: Medium\n-# implementationcost: Medium\n+# implementationcost: High\n ---\n-Without configured domain allow/deny lists for external collaboration, organizations lack essential domain-level access controls that act as the frontline defense in their security model. Domain allow/deny lists operate at the tenant level and take precedence over Cross-Tenant Access Policies (XTAP), blocking invitations from domains on the deny list regardless of cross-tenant access settings. While XTAP enables granular controls for specific trusted tenants, domain restrictions are critical for preventing invitations from unknown or unverified domains that haven't been explicitly allowed.\n+Limiting guest access to a known and approved list of tenants helps to prevent threat actors from exploiting unrestricted guest access to establish initial access through compromised external accounts or by creating accounts in untrusted tenants. Threat actors who gain access through an unrestricted domain can discover internal resources, users, and applications to perform additional attacks. \n \n-Without these restrictions, internal users can invite external accounts from any domain—including potentially compromised or attacker-controlled domains. Threat actors can register domains that appear legitimate to conduct social engineering attacks, tricking users into sending collaboration invitations that circumvent XTAP's targeted protections. Once granted access, these external guest accounts can be used for reconnaissance, mapping internal resources, user relationships, and collaboration patterns.\n-\n-These invited accounts provide persistent access that appears legitimate in audit logs and security monitoring systems. Attackers can maintain a long-term presence to collect data, access shared resources, documents, and applications configured for external collaboration, and potentially exfiltrate data through authorized channels without triggering alerts.\n+Organizations should take inventory and configure an allowlist or blocklist to control B2B collaboration invitations from specific organizations. Without these controls, threat actors might use social engineering techniques to obtain invitations from legitimate internal users. \n \n **Remediation action**\n-- [Configure domain-based allow or deny lists](../../external-id/allow-deny-list.md#set-the-allow-or-blocklist-policy-in-the-portal)\n\\ No newline at end of file\n+\n+- Learn how to [set up a list of approved domains](/entra/external-id/allow-deny-list#add-an-allowlist)." }, { "sha": "f834ee099f23e3c340b30b38b9f551fcee05f02d", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21893.md", "status": "added", "additions": 19, "deletions": 0, "changes": 19, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21893.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21893.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21893.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@\n+---\n+title: All users are required to register for MFA\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Access control\n+# risklevel: Low\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Require multifactor authentication (MFA) registration for all users. Based on studies, your account is more than 99% less likely to be compromised if you're using MFA. Even if you don't require MFA all the time, this policy ensures your users are ready when it's needed.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure the multifactor authentication registration policy](/entra/id-protection/howto-identity-protection-configure-mfa-policy)" }, { "sha": "29528d01d740db1bdb9d7d91f1201fa08484d446", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21953.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Local Admin Password Solution is deployed\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Devices\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Without Local Admin Password Solution (LAPS) deployed, threat actors exploit static local administrator passwords to establish initial access. After threat actors compromise a single device with a shared local administrator credential, they can move laterally across the environment and authenticate to other systems sharing the same password. Compromised local administrator access gives threat actors system-level privileges, letting them disable security controls, install persistent backdoors, exfiltrate sensitive data, and establish command and control channels. \n+\n+The automated password rotation and centralized management of LAPS closes this security gap and adds controls to help manage who has access to these critical accounts. Without solutions like LAPS, you can't detect or respond to unauthorized use of local administrator accounts, giving threat actors extended dwell time to achieve their objectives while remaining undetected.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure Windows Local Administrator Password Solution](/entra/identity/devices/howto-manage-local-admin-passwords)." }, { "sha": "30890702ed0fffdb212b6d60439bacc0ff6518d2", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/22072.md", "status": "added", "additions": 22, "deletions": 0, "changes": 22, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F22072.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F22072.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F22072.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@\n+---\n+title: Self-service password reset doesn't use security questions\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Allowing security questions as a self-service password reset (SSPR) method weakens the password reset process because answers are frequently guessable, reused across sites, or discoverable through open-source intelligence (OSINT). Threat actors enumerate or phish users, derive likely responses (family names, schools, and locations), and then trigger password reset flows to bypass stronger methods by exploiting the weaker knowledge-based gate. After they successfully reset a password on an account that isn't protected by multifactor authentication they can: gain valid primary credentials, establish session tokens, and laterally expand by registering more durable authentication methods, add forwarding rules, or exfiltrate sensitive data.\n+\n+Eliminating this method removes a weak link in the password reset process. Some organizations might have specific business reasons for leaving security questions enabled, but this isn't recommended.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Disable security questions in SSPR policy](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-security-questions)\n+- [Select authentication methods and registration options](/entra/identity/authentication/tutorial-enable-sspr#select-authentication-methods-and-registration-options)" } ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit updates several Microsoft Entra ID documentation pages, introducing new security recommendations and refining existing ones. Key changes include adding recommendations for passkey authentication, enforcing app secret standards, and limiting device registrations. The commit also enhances guidance on provisioning groups to Active Directory Domain Services by preserving original OU paths and updates tutorials for Britive SSO and provisioning. Additionally, it improves the bulk download functionality for groups and group members, making it more user-friendly.

ai_summary.Response: These commits refine the documentation for integrating Britive with Microsoft Entra ID. The changes primarily involve updating instructions for configuring Britive to support provisioning and single sign-on (SSO). Minor edits include correcting grammatical errors and ensuring consistent phrasing, such as changing "followin" to "following" and "Re-Create" to "Recreate token" for better clarity. Additionally, a few image files were updated, although the specific changes to these images are not detailed in the commit diffs.

changes.author: Shannon Leavitt
changes.message:
Merge pull request #1761 from hwan-britive/main

Update britive-tutorial.md as per the new Britive UI

The changes refine instructions for configuring Britive for provisioning and single sign-on (SSO), clarifying steps and button names. Minor adjustments were also made to the wording in the tutorials.

    "patch": "@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@ metadata:\n   ms.author: justinha\n   manager: dougeby\n   ms.reviewer: jupetter\n-  ms.date: 01/26/2025\n+  ms.date: 10/09/2025\n   ms.service: entra-id\n   ms.subservice: authentication\n   ms.topic: how-to\n@@ -106,10 +106,14 @@ procedureSection:\n         Choose the user you wish to perform an action on and select **Authentication methods**. At the top of the window, then choose one of the following options for the user:\n           - **Reset password** resets the user's password and assigns a temporary password that must be changed on the next sign-in.\n           - **Require re-register MFA** deactivates the user's hardware OATH tokens and deletes the following authentication methods from this user: phone numbers, Microsoft Authenticator apps and software OATH tokens. If needed, the user is requested to set up a new MFA authentication method the next time they sign in.\n-          - **Revoke MFA sessions** clears the user's remembered MFA sessions and requires them to perform MFA the next time it's required by the policy on the device.\n-              \n-          :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-mfa-userdevicesettings/manage-authentication-methods-in-azure.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of manage authentication methods from the Microsoft Entra admin center.\":::\n-  \n+          - **Revoke MFA sessions** forces users with enforced or enabled status in [per-user MFA](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-mfa-userstates) to complete MFA again by clearing their remembered sessions.  \n+ \n+            :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-mfa-userdevicesettings/manage-authentication-methods-in-azure.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of manage authentication methods from the Microsoft Entra admin center.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-mfa-userdevicesettings/manage-authentication-methods-in-azure.png\":::\n+\n+            Microsoft recommends using **Revoke sessions** instead because it signs out users from all active sessions. To revoke sessions for a user in the Microsoft Entra ID admin center, select **Users** > select a user > **Overview** > **Revoke sessions**.\n+\n+            :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-mfa-userdevicesettings/revoke-sessions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of how to revoke sessions for a user in the Microsoft Entra admin center.\":::\n+\n   - title: |\n       Delete users' existing app passwords\n     summary: |"

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for managing user multi-factor authentication (MFA) settings. The `ms.date` metadata has been advanced, and the explanation for "Revoke MFA sessions" has been clarified to recommend using the "Revoke sessions" feature for a more comprehensive sign-out experience. A new screenshot demonstrating how to revoke sessions for a user has also been added.

ai_summary.Response: The changes include updates to documentation regarding Global Secure Access support in China, clarifying that support is for tenants deployed outside China. There are also numerous additions and modifications to the documentation for Microsoft Entra ID Governance, specifically concerning application integrations, licensing requirements for member and guest users, and the prerequisites for various Entra ID Governance products. These updates aim to provide clearer guidance on licensing and feature availability within the Microsoft Entra ID ecosystem.

ai_summary.Response: This commit modifies the documentation regarding Global Secure Access support in China. The change clarifies that Microsoft *does* support Global Secure Access for tenants deployed outside China, even when users are physically located in China. It also reiterates that Global Secure Access is *not* currently supported for tenants deployed on Microsoft Azure within China. The update includes a minor wording adjustment for improved clarity on the supported scenario.

    "patch": "@@ -12,16 +12,13 @@ ms.reviewer: sumeetmittal\n # Customer intent: As an IT admin, I want to evaluate the regulatory constraints of using Global Secure Access in China so that I can ensure compliance and plan connectivity strategies effectively.   \n ---\n \n-# Global Secure Access support in China (Preview)\n+# Global Secure Access support in China\n Microsoft supports Global Secure Access capabilities in China, offering secure and compliant connectivity solutions tailored to the needs of organizations operating in China. \n \n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> Global Secure Access support in China is currently in PREVIEW.\n-> This information relates to a prerelease functionality that might be substantially modified before release. Microsoft makes no warranties, expressed or implied, with respect to the information provided in this article.\n-\n There are two scenarios that are applicable to Global Secure Access in China:      \n-- Global Secure Access availability for customer tenants deployed on Microsoft Azure in China. **Microsoft currently doesn’t support this scenario**. \n-- Global Secure Access availability for tenants outside China. This scenario includes use cases where Global Secure Access customers with a presence in multiple geographies make a temporary visit to China. For example, when an employee of USA-based company Contoso, using Global Secure Access, travels to China. **Microsoft supports this scenario**.    \n+- Global Secure Access availability for **customer tenants deployed on Microsoft Azure in China**. **Microsoft currently doesn’t support this scenario**. \n+- Global Secure Access availability for **customer tenants deployed on Microsoft Azure outside China**. **Microsoft supports this scenario**.\n+  - This scenario includes use cases where Global Secure Access (GSA) customers with a presence in multiple geographies and tenants deployed outside China use GSA while in China. For example, when an employee of USA-based company Contoso, using GSA, travels to China.     \n \n However, it’s important to recognize the specific connectivity disclaimers that apply to Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) providers operating in China. Because of regulatory restrictions and local infrastructure requirements, SASE providers might encounter:    \n - **Service limitations**: Connectivity performance can vary because of internet regulations and restrictions on VPN usage. Local routing policies can also affect network latency and bandwidth. Because connectivity is unpredictable, user experience might vary. "
  }

ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the changes:

The documentation for external identity for customers has been updated to include information on issuer acceleration for custom OIDC and SAML identity providers, along with new screenshots. Minor edits were made to the Global Secure Access documentation regarding prerequisites and support for China, clarifying the distinction between tenants hosted in China and those hosted outside China.

ai_summary.Response: This commit modifies a Microsoft Entra ID documentation page on entitlement management and requesting access on behalf of others. The changes introduce a prerequisite step for managers to configure "My Access" settings, specifically enabling the "View access package assignments for direct reports (preview)" option. This configuration is necessary before managers can view and manage their team's access package assignments through the My Access portal. New screenshots have been added to illustrate these configuration steps.

[Risky users](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#risky-users-report) such as accounts with [leaked credentials](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#investigating-leaked-credentials-detections) and [suspicious behavior](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#investigating-password-spray-detections).\n-1. [Risk detections](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#risk-detections-report) such as [token replay](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#investigating-anomalous-token-and-token-issuer-anomaly-detections) and unfamiliar sign-in properties.\n+1. [Risky sign-ins](../id-protection/concept-risk-reports.md#risky-sign-ins) such as [impossible travel](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#atypical-travel-detections), [anonymous IPs, and malware-linked IPs](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#malicious-ip-address-detections).\n+1. [Risk detections](../id-protection/concept-risk-reports.md#risk-detections) such as [token replay](../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#anomalous-token-and-token-issuer-anomaly-detections) and unfamiliar sign-in properties.\n \n ## Investigate with Microsoft Security Copilot in Microsoft Entra\n "

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/a9b015970a4e12c54628864c554bf9baa66fe8e9/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fconcept-cisco-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fconcept-cisco-coexistence.md?ref=a9b015970a4e12c54628864c554bf9baa66fe8e9",
    "patch": "@@ -1,79 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Learn about Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco.\n-description: Microsoft and Cisco’s Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence solution guide.\n-author: kenwith\n-ms.author: kenwith\n-manager: dougeby\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 02/21/2025\n-ms.service: global-secure-access\n-ms.subservice: entra-private-access \n-ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n-ai-usage: ai-assisted\n----\n-\n-# Learn about Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco\n-\n-Leverage Microsoft and Cisco’s Security Service Edge (SSE) solutions in a unified environment to harness a robust set of capabilities from both platforms and elevate your Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) journey. The synergy between these platforms empowers customers with enhanced security and seamless connectivity.\n-\n-This document contains steps to deploy these solutions side by side, specifically, Microsoft Entra Private Access (with Private DNS feature enabled) and Cisco Umbrella for internet access and DNS-layer security.\n- \n-## Configuration overview\n-\n-In Microsoft Entra, you enable the Private Access traffic forwarding profile and disable the Internet Access and Microsoft 365 traffic forwarding profiles. You also enable and configure the Private DNS feature of Private Access. In Cisco, you capture Internet Access traffic.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> The clients must be installed on a Windows 10 or Windows 11 Microsoft Entra joined device or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined device.\n-\n-## Microsoft Entra Private Access configuration\n-\n-Enable the Microsoft Entra Private Access traffic forwarding profile for your Microsoft Entra tenant. For more information about enabling and disabling profiles, see [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n-\n-Install and configure the Global Secure Access Client on end-user devices. For more information about clients, see [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md). To learn how to install the Windows client, see [Global Secure Access client for Windows](how-to-install-windows-client.md). \n-\n-Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector. To learn how to install and configure the connector, see [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Connector version v1.5.3829.0 or higher is required for Private DNS.\n-\n-Configure Quick Access to your private resources and set up Private DNS and DNS suffixes. To learn how to configure Quick Access, see [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n-\n-## Cisco configuration\n-\n-Add domain suffixes from Microsoft Entra Quick Access and Microsoft Entra service FQDN in Domain Management in Internal domains list to bypass Cisco’s Umbrella DNS. Add Microsoft Entra service FQDN and IPs in Domain Management in External domains list to bypass Cisco’s Secure Web Gateway (SWG).\n-1. From Cisco Umbrella portal, go to **Deployments > Configuration > Domain Management**.\n-1. In **Internal Domains** section, add these and save. \n-    - `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com` \n-        > [!NOTE]\n-        > Cisco Umbrella has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n-    - `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local` \n-        > [!NOTE]\n-        > `quickaccessapplicationid` is the application id of the quick access app you’ve configured.\n-    - DNS suffixes you’ve configured in the Quick Access application.\n-1. In the **External Domains & IPs** section, add these FQDN and IPs and save.\n-    -  `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com, 150.171.19.0/24, 150.171.20.0/24, 13.107.232.0/24, 13.107.233.0/24, 150.171.15.0/24, 150.171.18.0/24, 151.206.0.0/16, 6.6.0.0/16`\n-        > [!NOTE] \n-        > Cisco Umbrella has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com` for the FQDN.\n-1. Restart Cisco Umbrella and Cisco SWG client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n-\n-After both clients are installed and running side by side and configurations from admin portals are complete, go to the system tray to check that Global Secure Access and Cisco clients are enabled.\n-\n-Verify configuration for Global Secure Access client.\n-1. Right click on the **Global Secure Access client > Advanced Diagnostics > Forwarding Profile** and verify that only Private Access rules are applied to this client.\n-1. In **Advanced Diagnostics > Health Check** ensure no checks are failing.\n-\n-## Test traffic flow\n-Microsoft’s SSE configuration: Enable Microsoft Entra Private Access, disable Internet Access and Microsoft 365 traffic forwarding profiles.\n-\n-Cisco SSE configuration: Internet Access traffic is captured. The Private Access traffic is excluded.\n-\n-1. In the system tray, right-click the Global Secure Access client icon and then select **Advanced Diagnostics**. Select the **Traffic** tab and select **Start collecting**.\n-1. Access private resources you’ve configured with Entra Private Access such as SMB File share. Open `\\\\YourFileServer.yourdomain.com` by using the **Start/Run** menu from an explorer window.\n-1. In the system tray, right-click the Global Secure Access client and then select **Advanced Diagnostics**. In the **Network traffic** dialog box, select **Stop collecting**.\n-1. In the **Network traffic** dialog box, scroll to observe the traffic generated to confirm that Private Access traffic was handled by the Global Secure Access client.\n-1. You can also verify that the traffic is captured by Microsoft Entra by validating the traffic in the Global Secure Access traffic logs from Microsoft Entra admin center in **Global Secure Access > Monitor > Traffic logs**.\n-1. Access any websites from the browsers and validate that internet traffic is missing from Global Secure Access traffic logs and only captured in Cisco Umbrella.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)"

    "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ author: kenwith\n ms.author: kenwith\n manager: dougeby\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 07/29/2025\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n ms.service: global-secure-access\n ai-usage: ai-assisted\n ---\n@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@ This widget provides the following alerts:\n - **Unhealthy remote network**: An unhealthy remote network has one or more device links disconnected.\n - **Increased external tenants activity**: The number of users accessing external tenants has increased.\n - **Token and device inconsistency**: The original token is used on a different device.\n-- **Web content blocked**: Access to the website has been blocked.\n+- **Web content blocked**: Access to the website is blocked.\n \n ![Screenshot of the alerts and notifications widget showing two alert types.](media/concept-traffic-dashboard/dashboard-alerts-notifications.png)\n \n@@ -136,7 +136,7 @@ Select **View all web categories** to view more details about your network traff\n \n ## Device status\n \n-The **Device status** widgets display the active and inactive devices that you have deployed.\n+The **Device status** widgets display the active and inactive devices that you deployed.\n \n - **Active devices**: The number of distinct device IDs seen in the last 24 hours and the % change during that time.\n - **Inactive devices**: The number of distinct device IDs that were seen in the last seven days, but not during the last 24 hours. The % change during the last 24 hours is also displayed.\n@@ -153,14 +153,21 @@ The **Top used cloud applications** widget shows the most used cloud application\n The **Cloud applications status** widget displays the total number of cloud applications accessed by users and devices. The widget also shows the number of Generative AI applications, and the total number of high-risk applications accessed.\n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-traffic-dashboard/total-cloud-widget.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Cloud applications status widget showing the total cloud applications, the total Generative AI applications, and the total at-risk applications.\":::   \n \n+## Network activity by location (preview)\n+\n+The **Network activity by location** widget is an interactive map that shows connection, transaction, user, device, and remote network activity by location. Admins can visualize and analyze network activity based on the origin of source IP addresses. These geographic insights help with:\n+- Security monitoring: Identify traffic from high-risk regions and detect anomalies based on geographic patterns.\n+- Operational intelligence: Diagnose ISP-related issues and optimize routing decisions.\n+- Compliance support: Meet location-based regulatory requirements, such as regional data protection or data residency policies.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-traffic-dashboard/network-activity-by-location.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Network activity by location widget. One location is expanded to show more details.\" lightbox=\"media/concept-traffic-dashboard/network-activity-by-location-expanded.png\":::\n+\n ## No data available\n \n If your dashboard contains the **No data available** message, you need to onboard your tenant or configure the required settings to get data to appear on the dashboard. If you see this message, review the [Get started](how-to-get-started-with-global-secure-access.md) guide to onboard your tenant.\n \n ![Screenshot of a widget with no data available.](media/concept-traffic-dashboard/no-data-available.png)\n \n-\n-\n ## Next steps\n \n - [Explore the traffic logs](how-to-view-traffic-logs.md)"

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-coexistence.md?ref=de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,166 @@\n+---\n+title: Security Service Edge (SSE) Coexistence With Microsoft and Cisco Umbrella\n+description: Microsoft and Cisco’s Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence solution guide.\n+author: kenwith\n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: conceptual\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.subservice: entra-private-access \n+ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco Umbrella DNS protection\n+\n+Learn how to deploy Global Secure Access and Cisco Umbrella, with DNS security only, in a unified environment. This guide provides step-by-step instructions for configuring both platforms to enhance security and connectivity as part of your Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) strategy.\n+The configurations outlined apply to both Cisco Umbrella and Cisco Secure Access. Detailed instructions for configuring each portal are provided.\n+> [!NOTE]\n+   > These scenarios feature DNS security only. If you want to include Cisco's Secure Web Gateway, see the coexistence configurations in the [Cisco Secure Access guide](how-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md).\n+## Scenarios\n+\n+This guide covers the following coexistence scenarios:\n+\n+1. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security](#1-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-entra-microsoft-access-with-cisco-umbrella-dns-security).**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles Internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco Umbrella provides DNS security. Cisco Secure Web Gateway features should be disabled.\n+2. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.](#2-microsoft-entra-internet-access-microsoft-access-and-microsoft-entra-private-access-with-cisco-umbrella-dns-security)**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles Internet, Microsoft, and Private Access traffic. Cisco Umbrella handles DNS. Cisco Secure Web Gateway should be disabled.\n+\n+ \n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+1. Cisco SWG features must be disabled for these configurations.\n+1. Integration with Microsoft Entra ID is recommended for best user experience.\n+\n+### Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+To configure Global Secure Access:\n+\n+1. **Enable or disable traffic forwarding profiles** for your Microsoft Entra tenant.  \n+    See [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+2. **Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector** for Private Access applications.  \n+    See [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+3. **Configure Quick Access** to private resources and set up Private DNS and DNS suffixes.  \n+    See [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+4. **Install and configure the Global Secure Access client** on end-user devices.  \n+    See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md).\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Private Network Connectors are required for Private Access applications.\n+\n+### Cisco Umbrella setup\n+\n+To configure Cisco Umbrella:\n+\n+1. **Provision users and groups.**  \n+    Integration with Microsoft Entra ID is recommended. See Microsoft Entra ID SAML configuration guide for [Umbrella](/entra/identity/saas-apps/cisco-umbrella-tutorial) or [Cisco Secure Access](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-users-and-groups).\n+2. **Create a policy to block a destination or content for testing.**\n+    For detailed information, see [Umbrella policies](https://docs.umbrella.com/deployment-umbrella/docs/create-and-apply-policies) or [Cisco Secure Access Internet Access Rules documentation](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-internet-access-rules).\n+3. **Deploy and install the Cisco Secure Client.**  \n+    \n+  > [!IMPORTANT]\n+  > Cisco released a Cisco Secure Client (CSC) feature to improve coexistence with Global Secure Access. These steps need to be performed after the initial installation, or re-installation (not required to run again when upgrading), of CSC version 5.1.10.x (or later). \n+  > 1. Install Cisco Secure Client version 5.1.10.x.\n+  > 1. Open CMD prompt as an administrator and run these commands:\n+  > 1. `\"%ProgramFiles(x86)%\\Cisco\\Cisco Secure Client\\acsocktool.exe\" -slwm 10`\n+  > 1. `net stop csc_vpnagent && net stop acsock && net start csc_vpnagent`\n+\n+## Bypass configuration for coexistence\n+\n+### Bypass Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access required IPs in Global Secure Access\n+\n+1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+2. Under **Internet access policies**, select **View**.\n+3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+4. Enter the following IPs: `208.67.222.222, 208.67.220.220, 67.215.64.0/19, 146.112.0.0/16, 155.190.0.0/16, 185.60.84.0/22, 204.194.232.0/21, 208.67.216.0/21, 208.69.32.0/21`\n+5. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access\n+\n+#### [Cisco Umbrella Portal](#tab/cisco-umbrella-portal)\n+\n+1. Add domain suffixes and Microsoft Entra service FQDNs to the **Deployments > Configuration > Domain Management > Internal domains** list: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Umbrella supports implied wildcards, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+2. Add these Microsoft FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+3. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+  > [!NOTE]\n+  > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+4. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+5. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+#### [Cisco Secure Access Portal](#tab/cisco-secure-access-portal)\n+\n+1. Go to **Connect > End User Connectivity > Internet Security**.\n+2. In **Traffic Steering**, select **Add Destination > Bypass Secure Access**, add this FQDN, and save: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Secure Access has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+3. Add these Microsoft FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+4. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+5. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+6. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+## Configuration scenarios\n+\n+### 1. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure the required destinations bypasses. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-umbrellacisco-secure-access) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Disable the SWG for [Umbrella devices](https://docs.umbrella.com/umbrella-user-guide/docs/selective-enablement#disable-the-swg-module) or [Cisco Secure Access devices](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/edit-roaming-devices-internet-security-settings#disable-the-internet-security-settings).\n+1.  Install and configure Cisco Secure Client software with the Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `yelp.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do not** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites in the traffic tab.\n+    4. In the Umbrella or Cisco Secure Access portal, validate DNS traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourmicrosoftdomain>.sharepoint.com` in browsers.\n+    6. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites. \n+    7. Access a site blocked by Cisco and validate that the Cisco block page is displayed.\n+    8. In Global Secure Access, stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+### 2. Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Private Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install a private network connector.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and Private DNS.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure the required destinations bypasses. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-umbrellacisco-secure-access) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Disable the SWG for [Umbrella devices](https://docs.umbrella.com/umbrella-user-guide/docs/selective-enablement#disable-the-swg-module) or [Cisco Secure Access devices](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/edit-roaming-devices-internet-security-settings#disable-the-internet-security-settings).\n+1. Install and configure Cisco Secure Client software with the Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `yelp.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **don't** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites in the traffic tab.\n+    4. In the Umbrella or Cisco Secure Access portal, validate DNS traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourmicrosoftdomain>.sharepoint.com` in browsers.\n+    6. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites. \n+    7. Access a site blocked by Cisco and validate that the Cisco block page is displayed.\n+    8. Access a Microsoft Entra private application (for example, SMB file share) and validate that Global Secure Access **is** capturing traffic and Cisco isn't.\n+    9. In Global Secure Access, stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For troubleshooting health check failures, see [Troubleshoot the Global Secure Access client: Health check](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md).\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)"
  },
  {
    "sha": "0c65334d5a036f94423b29d670f543bff2219c32",
    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/how-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md",
    "status": "added",
