    "patch": "@@ -1,236 +1,172 @@\n ---\n-title: Investigate risk Microsoft Entra ID Protection\n+title: Investigate risk with Microsoft Entra ID Protection\n description: Learn how to investigate risky users, detections, and sign-ins in Microsoft Entra ID Protection.\n ms.service: entra-id-protection\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 08/06/2025\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n author: shlipsey3\n ms.author: sarahlipsey\n manager: pwongera\n ms.reviewer: cokoopma\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n ---\n-# How To: Investigate risk\n+# How to investigate risk\n \n-Microsoft Entra ID Protection provides organizations with reporting they can use to investigate identity risks in their environment. These reports include risky users, risky sign-ins, risky workload identities, and risk detections. Investigation of events is key to better understanding and identifying any weak points in your security strategy. All these reports allow for downloading of events in .CSV format or integration with other security solutions like a dedicated Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tool for further analysis. Organizations can also take advantage of Microsoft Defender and Microsoft Graph API integrations to aggregate data with other sources.\n+Microsoft Entra ID Protection provides several [risk reports](concept-risk-reports.md) that can be used to investigate identity risks in your environment. Investigation of events is key to better understanding and identifying any weak points in your security strategy. ID Protection reports can be archived for storage or integrated with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools for further analysis. Organizations can also take advantage of Microsoft Defender, Microsoft Sentinel, and Microsoft Graph API integrations to aggregate data with other sources.\n \n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-- The Microsoft Entra ID P2 or Microsoft Entra Suite license is required for full access to Microsoft Entra ID Protection features.\n-    - For a detailed list of capabilities for each license tier, see [What is Microsoft Entra ID Protection](overview-identity-protection.md).\n-- The [Global Reader](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-reader) role is the least privileged role required to **view the risk reports**.\n-- The [Reports Reader](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#reports-reader) role is the least privileged role required to **view the sign-in and audit logs**.\n-\n-## Navigating the reports\n-\n-The risk reports are found in the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) under **ID Protection**. You can navigate directly to the reports or view a summary of important insights in the dashboard view and navigate to the corresponding reports from there.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/view-high-risk-users-from-id-protection-dashboard.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the number of high risk users widget from the ID Protection dashboard.\":::\n-\n-Each report launches with a list of all detections for the period shown at the top of the report. Administrators can optionally filter and add or remove columns based on their preference. Administrators can download the data in .CSV or .JSON format for further processing.\n-\n-When administrators select one or multiple entries, options to confirm or dismiss the risks appear at the top of the report. Selecting an individual risk event opens a pane with more details to assist with investigations.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-heading.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the heading of the Risky users report showing the options available to administrators.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-heading.png\":::\n-\n-### Risky users report\n-\n-The risky users report includes all users whose accounts are currently or were considered at risk of compromise. Risky users should be investigated and remediated to prevent unauthorized access to resources. We recommend starting with high risk users due to the high confidence of compromise. [Learn more about what the levels signify](concept-risk-detection-types.md#risk-levels)\n-\n-#### Why is a user at risk?\n-\n-A user becomes a risky user when:\n-\n-- They have one or more risky sign-ins.\n-- They have one or more [risks](concept-identity-protection-risks.md) detected on their account, like leaked credentials. \n-\n-#### How to investigate risky users?\n-\n-To view and investigate risky users, navigate to the Risky users report and use the filters to manage the results. There's an option at the top of the page to add other columns such as risk level, status, and risk detail.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Risky users report showing examples of users at risk.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report.png\":::\n-\n-When administrators select an individual user, the Risky user details pane appears. Risky user details provide information like: user ID, office location, recent risky sign-in, detections not linked to a sign, and risk history. The Risk history tab shows the events that led to a user risk change in the last 90 days. This list includes risk detections that increased the user's risk. It can also include user or admin remediation actions that lowered the user's risk; for example, a user resetting their password or an admin dismissing the risk.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-risky-user-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Risky User Details flyout with samples of Risk history.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-risky-user-details.png\":::\n-\n-If you have Copilot for Security, you have access to a [summary in natural language](../security-copilot/entra-risky-user-summarization.md) including: why the user risk level was elevated, guidance on how to mitigate and respond, and links to other helpful items or documentation. \n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-risky-user-details-copilot-summary.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the summary of risk provided by Copilot in the Risky User Details flyout.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-risky-user-details-copilot-summary.png\":::\n-\n-With the information provided by the Risky users report, administrators can view:\n-\n-- User risk that was remediated, dismissed, or is still currently at risk and needs investigation\n-- Details about detections\n-- Risky sign-ins associated to a given user\n-- Risk history\n-\n-[!INCLUDE [id-protection-admin-action-user](../includes/id-protection-admin-action-user.md)]\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-risky-user-details-defender-investigate.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Risky User Details flyout and the additional actions an administrator might take.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-users-report-risky-user-details-defender-investigate.png\":::\n-\n-## Risky sign-ins report\n+There are many ways to investigate risk in your environment and even more details to consider during your investigation. This article provides a framework to help you get started and outlines some of the most common scenarios and recommended actions.\n \n-The risky sign-ins report contains filterable data for up to the past 30 days (one month). ID Protection evaluates risk for all authentication flows, whether it's interactive or non-interactive. The Risky sign-ins report shows both interactive and non-interactive sign-ins. To modify this view, use the \"sign-in type\" filter.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-sign-ins-report.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Risky sign-ins report.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risky-sign-ins-report.png\":::\n-\n-With the information provided by the Risky sign-ins report, administrators can view:\n-\n-- Sign-ins that are at risk, confirmed compromised, confirmed safe, dismissed, or remediated.\n-- Real-time and aggregate risk levels associated with sign-in attempts.\n-- Detection types triggered\n-- Conditional Access policies applied\n-- MFA details\n-- Device information\n-- Application information\n-- Location information\n-\n-[!INCLUDE [id-protection-admin-action-sign-in](../includes/id-protection-admin-action-sign-in.md)]\n-\n-To learn more about when to take each of these actions, see [How does Microsoft use my risk feedback](howto-identity-protection-risk-feedback.md#how-does-microsoft-use-my-risk-feedback)\n-\n-## Risk detections report\n-\n-The Risk detections report contains filterable data for up to the past 90 days (three months).\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risk-detections-report.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Risk detections report.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risk-detections-report.png\":::\n+## Prerequisites\n \n-With the information provided by the Risk detections report, administrators can find:\n+- [Microsoft Entra ID P2 or Microsoft Entra Suite license](overview-identity-protection.md) is required for full access to Microsoft Entra ID Protection features.\n+- [Global Reader](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-reader) is the least privileged role required to **view the risk reports**.\n+- [Reports Reader](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#reports-reader) is the least privileged role required to **view the sign-in and audit logs**.\n \n-- Information about each risk detection\n-- Attack type based on MITRE ATT&CK framework\n-- Other risks triggered at the same time\n-- Sign-in attempt location\n-- Link out to more detail from Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+## Initial triage\n \n-Administrators can then choose to return to the user's risk or sign-ins report to take actions based on information gathered.\n+When starting the initial triage, we recommend the following actions:\n \n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Our system might detect that the risk event that contributed to the user risk score was a false positive or the user risk was remediated with policy enforcement such as completing an MFA prompt or secure password change. Therefore, our system will dismiss the risk state and a risk detail of “AI confirmed sign-in safe” will surface and it will no longer contribute to the user's risk.\n+1. Review the [ID Protection dashboard](id-protection-dashboard.md) to visualize number of attacks, number of high risk users, and other important metrics based on detections in your environment.\n \n-## Initial triage\n+1. Review the [risk reports](concept-risk-reports.md) to examine the details of any recent risky users, sign-ins, or detections.\n \n-When starting the initial triage, we recommend the following actions:\n+1. Review the [Impact analysis workbook](workbook-risk-based-policy-impact.md) to understand the scenarios where risk is evident in your environment and what risk-based access policies should be enabled to manage high-risk users and sign-ins.\n \n-1. Review the ID Protection dashboard to visualize number of attacks, number of high risk users and other important metrics based on detections in your environment.\n-1. Review the Impact analysis workbook to understand the scenarios where risk is evident in your environment and risk-based access policies should be enabled to manage high-risk users and sign-ins.\n-1. Add corporate VPNs and IP address ranges to named locations to reduce false positives.\n-1. Consider creating a known traveler database for updated organizational travel reporting and use it to cross-reference travel activity.\n-1. Review the logs to identify similar activities with the same characteristics. This activity could be an indication of more compromised accounts.\n+1. Review the [sign-in logs](../identity/monitoring-health/concept-sign-ins.md) to identify similar activities with the same characteristics. This activity could be an indication of more compromised accounts.\n    1. If there are common characteristics, like IP address, geography, success/failure, etc., consider blocking them with a Conditional Access policy.\n    1. Review which resources might be compromised, including potential data downloads or administrative modifications.\n-   1. Enable self-remediation policies through Conditional Access\n-1. Check to see if the user performed other risky activities, such as downloading a large volume of files from a new location. This behavior is a strong indication of a possible compromise.\n+   1. Enable [self-remediation policies through Conditional Access](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md).\n+\n+1. With [Insider Risk Management through Microsoft Purview](/purview/insider-risk-management), you can check to see if the user performed other risky activities, such as downloading a large volume of files from a new location. This behavior is a strong indication of a possible compromise.\n \n If you suspect an attacker can impersonate the user, you should require the user to reset their password and perform MFA or block the user and revoke all refresh and access tokens.\n \n ## Investigation and risk remediation framework\n \n-Organizations can use the following framework to begin their investigation into any suspicious activity. The recommended first step is self-remediation, if it's an option. Self-remediation can take place through self-service password reset or through remediation flow of a risk-based Conditional Access policy.\n+Organizations can use the following framework to investigate suspicious activity. When risk is detected, the recommended first step is self-remediation, if it's an option. Self-remediation can take place through self-service password reset or through remediation flow of a [risk-based Conditional Access policy](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md).\n \n-If self-remediation isn't an option, an administrator needs to remediate the risk. Remediation is done by invoking a password reset, requiring user to reregister for MFA, blocking the user, or revoking user sessions depending on the scenario. The following flow chart shows the recommended flow once a risk is detected:\n+If self-remediation isn't an option, an administrator needs to remediate the risk. Remediation is done by invoking a password reset, requiring user to reregister for MFA, blocking the user, or revoking user sessions. The following flow chart shows the recommended flow once a risk is detected:\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risk-remediation-flow.png\" alt-text=\"Diagram showing the risk remediation flow.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/risk-remediation-flow.png\":::\n \n-Once the risk is contained, more investigation might be required to mark the risk as safe, compromised or to dismiss it. To come to a confident conclusion, it might be necessary to: have a conversation with the user in question, review the sign-in logs, review the audit logs, or query risk logs in Log Analytics. The following outlines recommended actions during this phase of the investigation:\n+Once the risk is contained, more investigation might be required to mark the risk as safe, compromised, or to dismiss it.\n \n-1. Check the logs and validate whether the activity is normal for the given user.\n+1. Check the sign-in logs and validate whether the activity is normal for the given user.\n    1. Look at the user's past activities including the following properties to see if they're normal for the given user.\n-      1. Application\n-      1. Device - Is the device registered or compliant?\n-      1. Location - Is the user traveling to a different location or accessing devices from multiple locations?\n-      1. IP address\n-      1. User agent string\n-   1. If you have access to other security tools like [Microsoft Sentinel](/azure/sentinel/overview), check for corresponding alerts that might indicate a larger issue.\n-   1. Organizations with access to [Microsoft Defender XDR](/defender-for-identity/understanding-security-alerts) can follow a user risk event through other related alerts, incidents, and the MITRE ATT&CK chain.\n-      1. To navigate from the Risky users report, select the user in the Risky users report and select the ellipsis (...) in the toolbar then choose Investigate with Microsoft Defender XDR.\n-1. Reach out to the user to confirm if they recognize the sign-in; however, consider methods such as email or Teams might be compromised.\n+      - Application - Is the app commonly used by the user?\n+      - Device - Is the device registered or compliant?\n+      - Location - Is the user traveling to a different location or accessing devices from multiple locations?\n+      - IP address\n+      - **User agent string**\n+\n+1. Investigate using other security tools, where available.\n+   - If you have [Microsoft Sentinel](/azure/sentinel/overview), check for corresponding alerts that might indicate a larger issue.\n+   - If you have [Microsoft Defender XDR](/defender-for-identity/understanding-security-alerts), you can follow a user risk event through other related alerts, incidents, and the **MITRE ATT&CK chain.**\n+      - To navigate from the **Risky users report**, select a user > select the ellipsis (...) > select **Investigate with Microsoft 365 Defender**.\n+      \n+      :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/investigate-with-microsoft-365-defender.png\" alt-text=\"Risky user details pane with the ellipsis and investigate in Microsoft Defender XDR option highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk/investigate-with-microsoft-365-defender.png\":::\n+ \n+1. Contact the user to confirm if they recognize the sign-in; however, keep in mind that email or Teams might be compromised.\n    1. Confirm the information you have such as:\n-      1. Timestamp\n-      1. Application\n-      1. Device\n-      1. Location\n-      1. IP address\n+      - Timestamp\n+      - Application\n+      - Device\n+      - Location\n+      - IP address\n 1. Depending on the results of the investigation, mark the user or sign-in as confirmed compromised, confirmed safe, or dismiss the risk.\n 1. [Set up risk-based Conditional Access policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md#enable-policies) to prevent similar attacks or to address any gaps in coverage.\n \n-### Investigate specific detections\n+## Investigate specific detections\n+\n+Certain risk detections require specific investigation steps. The following sections outline some of the most common risk detections and recommended actions.\n \n-#### Microsoft Entra threat intelligence\n+### Microsoft Entra threat intelligence\n \n To investigate a Microsoft Entra threat intelligence risk detection, follow these steps based on the information provided in the \"additional info\" field of the Risk Detection Details pane:\n \n-1. Sign-in was from a suspicious IP Address:\n+- If the sign-in was from a suspicious IP Address:\n    1. Confirm if the IP address shows suspicious behavior in your environment.\n    1. Does the IP generate a high number of failures for a user or set of users in your directory?\n    1. Is the traffic of the IP coming from an unexpected protocol or application, for example Exchange legacy protocols?\n    1. If the IP address corresponds to a cloud service provider, rule out that there are no legitimate enterprise applications running from the same IP.\n-1. This account was the victim of a password spray attack:\n+\n+- Account was the victim of a password spray attack\n    1. Validate that no other users in your directory are targets of the same attack.\n-   1. Do other users have sign-ins with similar atypical patterns seen in the detected sign-in within the same time frame? Password spray attacks might display unusual patterns in:\n-      1. User agent string\n-      1. Application\n-      1. Protocol\n-      1. Ranges of IPs/ASNs\n-      1. Time and frequency of sign-ins\n-1. This detection was triggered by a real-time rule:\n+   1. Determine if other users have sign-ins with similar atypical patterns seen in the detected sign-in within the same time frame. Password spray attacks might display unusual patterns in:\n+      - User agent string\n+      - Application\n+      - Protocol\n+      - Ranges of IPs/ASNs\n+      - Time and frequency of sign-ins\n+\n+- Detection was triggered by a real-time rule\n    1. Validate that no other users in your directory are targets of the same attack. This information can be found using the TI_RI_#### number assigned to the rule.\n    1. Real-time rules protect against novel attacks identified by Microsoft's threat intelligence. If multiple users in your directory were targets of the same attack, investigate unusual patterns in other attributes of the sign in.\n \n-#### Investigating atypical travel detections\n+### Atypical travel detections\n+\n+- If you confirm the activity was *not* performed by a legitimate user:\n+   1. Mark the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation.\n+   1. Block the user if attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password.\n+- If a user is known to use the IP address in the scope of their duties, confirm sign-in as safe.\n+- If you confirm that the user recently traveled to the destination mentioned detailed in the alert, confirm sign-in as safe.\n+- If you confirm that the IP address range is from a sanctioned VPN, confirm sign-in as safe and add the VPN IP address range to named locations in Microsoft Entra ID and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+\n+### Anomalous token and token issuer anomaly detections\n \n-1. If you're able to confirm the activity wasn't performed by a legitimate user:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Mark the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation. Block user if attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password.\n-1. If a user is known to use the IP address in the scope of their duties:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Confirm sign-in as safe.\n-1. If you're able to confirm that the user recently traveled to the destination mentioned detailed in the alert:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Confirm sign-in as safe.\n-1. If you're able to confirm that the IP address range is from a sanctioned VPN.\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Confirm sign-in as safe and add the VPN IP address range to named locations in Microsoft Entra ID and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+- If you confirm that the activity was *not* performed by a legitimate user using a combination of risk alert, location, application, IP address, User Agent, or other characteristics that are unexpected for the user:\n+   1. Mark the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation.\n+   1. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform.\n+   1. [Set up risk-based Conditional Access policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md#enable-policies) to require password reset, perform MFA, or block access for all high-risk sign-ins.\n \n-#### Investigating anomalous token and token issuer anomaly detections\n+- If you confirm location, application, IP address, User Agent, or other characteristics are expected for the user and there aren't other indications of compromise, allow the user to self-remediate with a risk-based Conditional Access policy or have an admin confirm sign-in as safe.\n \n-1. If you're able to confirm that the activity wasn't performed by a legitimate user using a combination of risk alert, location, application, IP address, User Agent, or other characteristics that are unexpected for the user:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Mark the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform.\n-   1. **Recommended action**: [Set up risk-based Conditional Access policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md#enable-policies) to require password reset, perform MFA, or block access for all high-risk sign-ins.\n-1. If you're able to confirm location, application, IP address, User Agent, or other characteristics are expected for the user and there aren't other indications of compromise:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Allow the user to self-remediate with a risk-based Conditional Access policy or have an admin confirm sign-in as safe.\n-1. For further investigation of token based detections, see the blog post [Token tactics: How to prevent, detect, and respond to cloud token theft](https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/11/16/token-tactics-how-to-prevent-detect-and-respond-to-cloud-token-theft) the [Token theft investigation playbook](/security/operations/token-theft-playbook).\n+For further investigation of token based detections, see the blog post [Token tactics: How to prevent, detect, and respond to cloud token theft](https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/11/16/token-tactics-how-to-prevent-detect-and-respond-to-cloud-token-theft) the [Token theft investigation playbook](/security/operations/token-theft-playbook).\n \n-#### Investigating suspicious browser detections\n+### Suspicious browser detections\n \n-- Browser isn't commonly used by the user or activity within the browser doesn't match the users normally behavior.\n-   - **Recommended action**: Confirm the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA.\n-   - **Recommended action**: [Set up risk-based Conditional Access policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md#enable-policies) to require password reset, perform MFA, or block access for all high-risk sign-ins.\n+This detection indicates the user doesn't commonly use the browser or activity within the browser doesn't match the user's normal behavior.\n \n-#### Investigating malicious IP address detections\n+- Confirm the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA.\n+- [Set up risk-based Conditional Access policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md#enable-policies) to require password reset, perform MFA, or block access for all high-risk sign-ins.\n \n-1. If you're able to confirm that the activity wasn't performed by a legitimate user:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Confirm the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password and revoke all tokens.\n-   1. **Recommended action**: [Set up risk-based Conditional Access policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md#enable-policies) to require password reset or perform MFA for all high-risk sign-ins.\n-1. If a user is known to use the IP address in the scope of their duties:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Confirm sign-in as safe.\n+### Malicious IP address detections\n \n-#### Investigating password spray detections\n+- If you confirm that the activity was *not* performed by a legitimate user:\n+   1. Confirm the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation.\n+   1. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password and revoke all tokens.\n+   1. [Set up risk-based Conditional Access policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md#enable-policies) to require password reset or perform MFA for all high-risk sign-ins.\n \n-1. If you're able to confirm that the activity wasn't performed by a legitimate user:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Mark the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password and revoke all tokens.\n-1. If a user is known to use the IP address in the scope of their duties:\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Confirm sign-in safe.\n-1. If you're able to confirm that the account isn't compromised and see no brute force or password spray indicators against the account.\n-   1. **Recommended action**: Allow the user to self-remediate with a risk-based Conditional Access policy or have an admin confirm sign-in as safe.\n-1. Ensure you have [Microsoft Entra smart lockout](../identity/authentication/howto-password-smart-lockout.md) configured appropriately to avoid unnecessary account lockouts.\n+- If you confirm the user *does* use the IP address in the scope of their duties, confirm the sign-in as safe.\n+\n+### Password spray detections\n+\n+- If you confirm that the activity was *not* performed by a legitimate user:\n+   1. Mark the sign-in as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation.\n+   1. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password and revoke all tokens.\n+\n+- If you confirm the user *does* use the IP address in the scope of their duties, confirm the sign-in as safe.\n+\n+- If you confirm that the account isn't compromised and see no brute force or password spray indicators against the account:\n+   1. Allow the user to self-remediate with a risk-based Conditional Access policy or have an admin confirm sign-in as safe.\n+   1. Ensure you have [Microsoft Entra smart lockout](../identity/authentication/howto-password-smart-lockout.md) configured appropriately to avoid unnecessary account lockouts.\n \n For further investigation of password spray risk detections, see the article [Password spray investigation](/security/operations/incident-response-playbook-password-spray).\n \n-#### Investigating leaked credentials detections\n+### Leaked credentials detections\n+\n+If this detection identified a leaked credential for a user:\n+1. Confirm the user as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation.\n+1. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password and revoke all tokens.\n+\n+## Mitigate future risks\n \n-- If this detection identified a leaked credential for a user:\n-   - **Recommended action**: Confirm the user as compromised, and invoke a password reset if not already performed by self-remediation. Block the user if an attacker has access to reset password or perform MFA and reset password and revoke all tokens.\n+- Add corporate VPNs and IP address ranges to [named locations](../identity/conditional-access/concept-assignment-network.md) in your Conditional Access policies to reduce false positives.\n+- Consider creating a known traveler database for updated organizational travel reporting and use it to cross-reference travel activity.\n+- [Provide feedback in ID Protection](howto-identity-protection-risk-feedback.md) to improve detection accuracy and reduce false positives. \n \n ## Next steps\n \n - [Remediate and unblock users](howto-identity-protection-remediate-unblock.md)\n - [Policies available to mitigate risks](concept-identity-protection-policies.md)\n-- [Enable sign-in and user risk policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md)\n+- [Enable sign-in and user risk policies](howto-identity-protection-configure-risk-policies.md)\n\\ No newline at end of file"

    "patch": "@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@ title: Microsoft Entra ID Protection overview\n description: Learn how the Microsoft Entra ID Protection overview dashboard provides a view into security posture.\n ms.service: entra-id-protection\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 06/05/2025\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n author: shlipsey3\n ms.author: sarahlipsey\n manager: pmwongera\n@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@ Microsoft Entra ID Protection prevents identity compromises by detecting identit\n \n Our dashboard helps customers better analyze their security posture, understand how well they're protected, identify vulnerabilities, and perform recommended actions. \n \n-[![Screenshot showing the Microsoft Entra ID Protection overview dashboard.](./media/id-protection-dashboard/microsoft-entra-id-protection-dashboard.png)](./media/id-protection-dashboard/microsoft-entra-id-protection-dashboard.png)\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/id-protection-dashboard/full-dashboard.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Microsoft Entra ID Protection overview dashboard.\" lightbox=\"media/id-protection-dashboard/full-dashboard-expanded.png\":::\n \n This dashboard empowers organizations with rich insights and actionable recommendations tailored to your tenant. This information provides a better view into your organization’s security posture and lets you enable effective protections accordingly. You have access to key metrics, attack graphics, a map highlighting risky locations, top recommendations to enhance security posture, and recent activities.\n \n@@ -62,7 +62,7 @@ To help you better understand your risk exposure, our attack graphic displays co\n \n [![Screenshot showing the attack graphic in the dashboard.](./media/id-protection-dashboard/microsoft-entra-id-protection-dashboard-attack-graphic.png)](./media/id-protection-dashboard/microsoft-entra-id-protection-dashboard-attack-graphic.png)\n \n-#### What is considered an attack in Microsoft Entra ID Protection?\n+#### What is considered as an attack in Microsoft Entra ID Protection?\n \n An attack is an event where we detect a bad actor attempting to sign-in to your environment. This event triggers a real-time sign-in [risk detection](concept-risk-detection-types.md) mapped to a corresponding MITRE ATT&CK technique. Refer to the following table for the mapping between Microsoft Entra ID Protection’s real-time sign-in risk detections and attacks as categorized by MITRE ATT&CK techniques. \n "

    "patch": "@@ -23,11 +23,11 @@ With these integrations, you can enable rich visualizations, monitoring, and ale\n \n The following logs can be integrated with one of many endpoints:\n \n-* The [**audit logs activity report**](concept-audit-logs.md) gives you access to the history of every task performed in your tenant.\n-* With the [**sign-in activity report**](concept-sign-ins.md), you can see when users attempt to sign in to your applications or troubleshoot sign-in errors.\n+* The [**audit logs**](concept-audit-logs.md) gives you access to the history of every task performed in your tenant.\n+* With the [**sign-in logs**](concept-sign-ins.md), you can see when users attempt to sign in to your applications or troubleshoot sign-in errors.\n * With the [**provisioning logs**](../../identity/app-provisioning/application-provisioning-log-analytics.md), you can monitor which users were, updated, and deleted in all your non-Microsoft applications.\n-* The [**risky users logs**](../../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#risky-users-report) helps you monitor changes in user risk level and remediation activity.\n-* With the [**risk detections logs**](../../id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#risk-detections-report), you can monitor user's risk detections and analyze trends in risk activity detected in your organization.\n+* The [**risky users report**](../../id-protection/concept-risk-reports.md#risky-users) helps you monitor changes in user risk level and remediation activity.\n+* With the [**risk detections report**](../../id-protection/concept-risk-reports.md#risk-detections), you can monitor user's risk detections and analyze trends in risk activity detected in your organization.\n \n ## Integration options\n "

    "patch": "@@ -3,11 +3,11 @@ author: joflore\n ms.service: entra-id-protection\n \n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 08/20/2024\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n ms.author: joflore\n ---\n \n-Administrators can take action on risky sign-in events and choose to:\n+If the action buttons are greyed out, you need a higher privileged role. Administrators can take action on users and choose to:\n \n - **Reset password** - This action revokes user's current sessions.\n - **Confirm user compromised** - This action is taken on a true positive. ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates documentation for Microsoft Entra, focusing on the following areas:

*   **Global Secure Access:** Introduces new coexistence guides for Cisco Umbrella, Cisco Secure Access, Cisco VPNs, and updates existing guides for Palo Alto Networks and Zscaler. It also enhances the traffic dashboard with a new network activity by location widget.
*   **Identity Protection:** Refines the investigation process by introducing a new "Risk reports" concept page and updating the "How to investigate risk" article to align with new reporting structures and investigation frameworks.
*   **Entitlement Management:** Removes the "Preview" tag from "Request access packages on-behalf-of other users" and introduces new "Manage team assignments" functionality in the My Access portal.
*   **General Updates:** Includes minor updates to redirection rules and image files.

    "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ author: kenwith\n ms.author: kenwith\n manager: dougeby\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 07/29/2025\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n ms.service: global-secure-access\n ai-usage: ai-assisted\n ---\n@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@ This widget provides the following alerts:\n - **Unhealthy remote network**: An unhealthy remote network has one or more device links disconnected.\n - **Increased external tenants activity**: The number of users accessing external tenants has increased.\n - **Token and device inconsistency**: The original token is used on a different device.\n-- **Web content blocked**: Access to the website has been blocked.\n+- **Web content blocked**: Access to the website is blocked.\n \n ![Screenshot of the alerts and notifications widget showing two alert types.](media/concept-traffic-dashboard/dashboard-alerts-notifications.png)\n \n@@ -136,7 +136,7 @@ Select **View all web categories** to view more details about your network traff\n \n ## Device status\n \n-The **Device status** widgets display the active and inactive devices that you have deployed.\n+The **Device status** widgets display the active and inactive devices that you deployed.\n \n - **Active devices**: The number of distinct device IDs seen in the last 24 hours and the % change during that time.\n - **Inactive devices**: The number of distinct device IDs that were seen in the last seven days, but not during the last 24 hours. The % change during the last 24 hours is also displayed.\n@@ -153,14 +153,21 @@ The **Top used cloud applications** widget shows the most used cloud application\n The **Cloud applications status** widget displays the total number of cloud applications accessed by users and devices. The widget also shows the number of Generative AI applications, and the total number of high-risk applications accessed.\n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-traffic-dashboard/total-cloud-widget.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Cloud applications status widget showing the total cloud applications, the total Generative AI applications, and the total at-risk applications.\":::   \n \n+## Network activity by location (preview)\n+\n+The **Network activity by location** widget is an interactive map that shows connection, transaction, user, device, and remote network activity by location. Admins can visualize and analyze network activity based on the origin of source IP addresses. These geographic insights help with:\n+- Security monitoring: Identify traffic from high-risk regions and detect anomalies based on geographic patterns.\n+- Operational intelligence: Diagnose ISP-related issues and optimize routing decisions.\n+- Compliance support: Meet location-based regulatory requirements, such as regional data protection or data residency policies.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-traffic-dashboard/network-activity-by-location.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Network activity by location widget. One location is expanded to show more details.\" lightbox=\"media/concept-traffic-dashboard/network-activity-by-location-expanded.png\":::\n+\n ## No data available\n \n If your dashboard contains the **No data available** message, you need to onboard your tenant or configure the required settings to get data to appear on the dashboard. If you see this message, review the [Get started](how-to-get-started-with-global-secure-access.md) guide to onboard your tenant.\n \n ![Screenshot of a widget with no data available.](media/concept-traffic-dashboard/no-data-available.png)\n \n-\n-\n ## Next steps\n \n - [Explore the traffic logs](how-to-view-traffic-logs.md)"
  },

ai_summary.Response: The commit updates documentation for the Global Secure Access traffic dashboard. Key changes include an update to the `ms.date` metadata, a minor phrasing adjustment in the alerts section, and the addition of a new "Network activity by location (preview)" widget. This new widget provides a geographical visualisation of network activity, aiding in security monitoring, operational intelligence, and compliance support. Two new image files related to this widget have also been added.

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/6bb4eab033cf848eb6adc6dd76a164d88425080f/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fconcept-cisco-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fconcept-cisco-coexistence.md?ref=6bb4eab033cf848eb6adc6dd76a164d88425080f",
    "patch": "@@ -1,79 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Learn about Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco.\n-description: Microsoft and Cisco’s Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence solution guide.\n-author: kenwith\n-ms.author: kenwith\n-manager: dougeby\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 02/21/2025\n-ms.service: global-secure-access\n-ms.subservice: entra-private-access \n-ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n-ai-usage: ai-assisted\n----\n-\n-# Learn about Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco\n-\n-Leverage Microsoft and Cisco’s Security Service Edge (SSE) solutions in a unified environment to harness a robust set of capabilities from both platforms and elevate your Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) journey. The synergy between these platforms empowers customers with enhanced security and seamless connectivity.\n-\n-This document contains steps to deploy these solutions side by side, specifically, Microsoft Entra Private Access (with Private DNS feature enabled) and Cisco Umbrella for internet access and DNS-layer security.\n- \n-## Configuration overview\n-\n-In Microsoft Entra, you enable the Private Access traffic forwarding profile and disable the Internet Access and Microsoft 365 traffic forwarding profiles. You also enable and configure the Private DNS feature of Private Access. In Cisco, you capture Internet Access traffic.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> The clients must be installed on a Windows 10 or Windows 11 Microsoft Entra joined device or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined device.\n-\n-## Microsoft Entra Private Access configuration\n-\n-Enable the Microsoft Entra Private Access traffic forwarding profile for your Microsoft Entra tenant. For more information about enabling and disabling profiles, see [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n-\n-Install and configure the Global Secure Access Client on end-user devices. For more information about clients, see [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md). To learn how to install the Windows client, see [Global Secure Access client for Windows](how-to-install-windows-client.md). \n-\n-Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector. To learn how to install and configure the connector, see [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Connector version v1.5.3829.0 or higher is required for Private DNS.\n-\n-Configure Quick Access to your private resources and set up Private DNS and DNS suffixes. To learn how to configure Quick Access, see [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n-\n-## Cisco configuration\n-\n-Add domain suffixes from Microsoft Entra Quick Access and Microsoft Entra service FQDN in Domain Management in Internal domains list to bypass Cisco’s Umbrella DNS. Add Microsoft Entra service FQDN and IPs in Domain Management in External domains list to bypass Cisco’s Secure Web Gateway (SWG).\n-1. From Cisco Umbrella portal, go to **Deployments > Configuration > Domain Management**.\n-1. In **Internal Domains** section, add these and save. \n-    - `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com` \n-        > [!NOTE]\n-        > Cisco Umbrella has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n-    - `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local` \n-        > [!NOTE]\n-        > `quickaccessapplicationid` is the application id of the quick access app you’ve configured.\n-    - DNS suffixes you’ve configured in the Quick Access application.\n-1. In the **External Domains & IPs** section, add these FQDN and IPs and save.\n-    -  `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com, 150.171.19.0/24, 150.171.20.0/24, 13.107.232.0/24, 13.107.233.0/24, 150.171.15.0/24, 150.171.18.0/24, 151.206.0.0/16, 6.6.0.0/16`\n-        > [!NOTE] \n-        > Cisco Umbrella has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com` for the FQDN.\n-1. Restart Cisco Umbrella and Cisco SWG client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n-\n-After both clients are installed and running side by side and configurations from admin portals are complete, go to the system tray to check that Global Secure Access and Cisco clients are enabled.\n-\n-Verify configuration for Global Secure Access client.\n-1. Right click on the **Global Secure Access client > Advanced Diagnostics > Forwarding Profile** and verify that only Private Access rules are applied to this client.\n-1. In **Advanced Diagnostics > Health Check** ensure no checks are failing.\n-\n-## Test traffic flow\n-Microsoft’s SSE configuration: Enable Microsoft Entra Private Access, disable Internet Access and Microsoft 365 traffic forwarding profiles.\n-\n-Cisco SSE configuration: Internet Access traffic is captured. The Private Access traffic is excluded.\n-\n-1. In the system tray, right-click the Global Secure Access client icon and then select **Advanced Diagnostics**. Select the **Traffic** tab and select **Start collecting**.\n-1. Access private resources you’ve configured with Entra Private Access such as SMB File share. Open `\\\\YourFileServer.yourdomain.com` by using the **Start/Run** menu from an explorer window.\n-1. In the system tray, right-click the Global Secure Access client and then select **Advanced Diagnostics**. In the **Network traffic** dialog box, select **Stop collecting**.\n-1. In the **Network traffic** dialog box, scroll to observe the traffic generated to confirm that Private Access traffic was handled by the Global Secure Access client.\n-1. You can also verify that the traffic is captured by Microsoft Entra by validating the traffic in the Global Secure Access traffic logs from Microsoft Entra admin center in **Global Secure Access > Monitor > Traffic logs**.\n-1. Access any websites from the browsers and validate that internet traffic is missing from Global Secure Access traffic logs and only captured in Cisco Umbrella.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)"

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-coexistence.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-coexistence.md?ref=eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,166 @@\n+---\n+title: Security Service Edge (SSE) Coexistence With Microsoft and Cisco Umbrella\n+description: Microsoft and Cisco’s Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence solution guide.\n+author: kenwith\n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: conceptual\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.subservice: entra-private-access \n+ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco Umbrella DNS protection\n+\n+Learn how to deploy Global Secure Access and Cisco Umbrella, with DNS security only, in a unified environment. This guide provides step-by-step instructions for configuring both platforms to enhance security and connectivity as part of your Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) strategy.\n+The configurations outlined apply to both Cisco Umbrella and Cisco Secure Access. Detailed instructions for configuring each portal are provided.\n+> [!NOTE]\n+   > These scenarios feature DNS security only. If you want to include Cisco's Secure Web Gateway, see the coexistence configurations in the [Cisco Secure Access guide](how-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md).\n+## Scenarios\n+\n+This guide covers the following coexistence scenarios:\n+\n+1. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security](#1-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-entra-microsoft-access-with-cisco-umbrella-dns-security).**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles Internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco Umbrella provides DNS security. Cisco Secure Web Gateway features should be disabled.\n+2. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.](#2-microsoft-entra-internet-access-microsoft-access-and-microsoft-entra-private-access-with-cisco-umbrella-dns-security)**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles Internet, Microsoft, and Private Access traffic. Cisco Umbrella handles DNS. Cisco Secure Web Gateway should be disabled.\n+\n+ \n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+1. Cisco SWG features must be disabled for these configurations.\n+1. Integration with Microsoft Entra ID is recommended for best user experience.\n+\n+### Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+To configure Global Secure Access:\n+\n+1. **Enable or disable traffic forwarding profiles** for your Microsoft Entra tenant.  \n+    See [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+2. **Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector** for Private Access applications.  \n+    See [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+3. **Configure Quick Access** to private resources and set up Private DNS and DNS suffixes.  \n+    See [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+4. **Install and configure the Global Secure Access client** on end-user devices.  \n+    See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md).\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Private Network Connectors are required for Private Access applications.\n+\n+### Cisco Umbrella setup\n+\n+To configure Cisco Umbrella:\n+\n+1. **Provision users and groups.**  \n+    Integration with Microsoft Entra ID is recommended. See Microsoft Entra ID SAML configuration guide for [Umbrella](/entra/identity/saas-apps/cisco-umbrella-tutorial) or [Cisco Secure Access](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-users-and-groups).\n+2. **Create a policy to block a destination or content for testing.**\n+    For detailed information, see [Umbrella policies](https://docs.umbrella.com/deployment-umbrella/docs/create-and-apply-policies) or [Cisco Secure Access Internet Access Rules documentation](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-internet-access-rules).\n+3. **Deploy and install the Cisco Secure Client.**  \n+    \n+  > [!IMPORTANT]\n+  > Cisco released a Cisco Secure Client (CSC) feature to improve coexistence with Global Secure Access. These steps need to be performed after the initial installation, or re-installation (not required to run again when upgrading), of CSC version 5.1.10.x (or later). \n+  > 1. Install Cisco Secure Client version 5.1.10.x.\n+  > 1. Open CMD prompt as an administrator and run these commands:\n+  > 1. `\"%ProgramFiles(x86)%\\Cisco\\Cisco Secure Client\\acsocktool.exe\" -slwm 10`\n+  > 1. `net stop csc_vpnagent && net stop acsock && net start csc_vpnagent`\n+\n+## Bypass configuration for coexistence\n+\n+### Bypass Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access required IPs in Global Secure Access\n+\n+1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+2. Under **Internet access policies**, select **View**.\n+3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+4. Enter the following IPs: `208.67.222.222, 208.67.220.220, 67.215.64.0/19, 146.112.0.0/16, 155.190.0.0/16, 185.60.84.0/22, 204.194.232.0/21, 208.67.216.0/21, 208.69.32.0/21`\n+5. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access\n+\n+#### [Cisco Umbrella Portal](#tab/cisco-umbrella-portal)\n+\n+1. Add domain suffixes and Microsoft Entra service FQDNs to the **Deployments > Configuration > Domain Management > Internal domains** list: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Umbrella supports implied wildcards, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+2. Add these Microsoft FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+3. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+  > [!NOTE]\n+  > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+4. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+5. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+#### [Cisco Secure Access Portal](#tab/cisco-secure-access-portal)\n+\n+1. Go to **Connect > End User Connectivity > Internet Security**.\n+2. In **Traffic Steering**, select **Add Destination > Bypass Secure Access**, add this FQDN, and save: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Secure Access has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+3. Add these Microsoft FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+4. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+5. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+6. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+## Configuration scenarios\n+\n+### 1. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure the required destinations bypasses. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-umbrellacisco-secure-access) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Disable the SWG for [Umbrella devices](https://docs.umbrella.com/umbrella-user-guide/docs/selective-enablement#disable-the-swg-module) or [Cisco Secure Access devices](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/edit-roaming-devices-internet-security-settings#disable-the-internet-security-settings).\n+1.  Install and configure Cisco Secure Client software with the Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `yelp.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do not** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites in the traffic tab.\n+    4. In the Umbrella or Cisco Secure Access portal, validate DNS traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourmicrosoftdomain>.sharepoint.com` in browsers.\n+    6. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites. \n+    7. Access a site blocked by Cisco and validate that the Cisco block page is displayed.\n+    8. In Global Secure Access, stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+### 2. Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Private Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install a private network connector.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and Private DNS.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure the required destinations bypasses. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-umbrellacisco-secure-access) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Disable the SWG for [Umbrella devices](https://docs.umbrella.com/umbrella-user-guide/docs/selective-enablement#disable-the-swg-module) or [Cisco Secure Access devices](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/edit-roaming-devices-internet-security-settings#disable-the-internet-security-settings).\n+1. Install and configure Cisco Secure Client software with the Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `yelp.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **don't** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites in the traffic tab.\n+    4. In the Umbrella or Cisco Secure Access portal, validate DNS traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourmicrosoftdomain>.sharepoint.com` in browsers.\n+    6. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites. \n+    7. Access a site blocked by Cisco and validate that the Cisco block page is displayed.\n+    8. Access a Microsoft Entra private application (for example, SMB file share) and validate that Global Secure Access **is** capturing traffic and Cisco isn't.\n+    9. In Global Secure Access, stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For troubleshooting health check failures, see [Troubleshoot the Global Secure Access client: Health check](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md).\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)"
  },

    "sha": "0c65334d5a036f94423b29d670f543bff2219c32",
    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/how-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md",
    "status": "added",
